name: NPR
text:
Colorado's governor has pardoned the "Balloon Boy" parents, who in 2009 claimed a large balloon had taken their son thousands of feet into the air. 

They pleaded guilty to a few crimes after authorities said it was a hoax.
https://t.co/b0xjjeOgs6

name: NPR
text:
This year's Christmas Eve Mass at St. Peter's Basilica had only 100 or so attendees â€” all of whom wore masks, except the pope and a small choir. 
 
https://t.co/uYgKv34AGg

name: NPR
text:
New modeling suggests the U.K. coronavirus variant is about 50% more transmissible than previous versions. Scientists don't know why yet â€” but urge diligence in mask-wearing, hand-washing and social distancing.
https://t.co/JmCYEkqkCb

name: NPR
text: It was just Day 2 of competition for the fledgling NBA season, but it's already off to a bumpy start. After 3 Rockets players returned coronavirus tests that were either positive or inconclusive, their match up with Oklahoma City was postponed. https://t.co/Ow94n0YwKy

name: NPR
text:
RT @reeseoxner: The so-called balloon boy incident captivated television audiences in 2009 as the parents of a 6-year-old named Falcon reported he had been carried away in a large, UFO-like balloon, thousands of feet in the air. 

But he never was in the balloon.

https://t.co/ctKhQuIDa8

name: NPR
text: RT @Lucian_Kim: Putin is counting on Sputnik V to stop the spread of the coronavirus in Russiaâ€”but faces widespread reluctance among ordinary Russians to get vaccinated. My report from Moscow: https://t.co/WCMM122Jdw

name: NPR
text:
The Columbus police chief recommended officer Adam Coy be dismissed from the force after he shot and killed a 47-year-old Black man, Andre Maurice Hill, less than 10 seconds after finding him in a garage on Tuesday.
https://t.co/IPIKLJSgdh

name: NPR
text:
"We have no ICU beds," said a chief medical officer at one of LA's largest hospitals. "We are just continually, 24 hours a day, scrambling to move patients around. The flood just continues."
https://t.co/B0XWzRSgGn

name: NPR
text:
Since 2011, this Baltimore duo has donned Santa suits and delivered BBQ and Christmas trees to adorning locals.

Not even a pandemic could stop the holiday tradition.

"A tree and a smile mean more now," Mike Santoro says.
https://t.co/oSo47eXI6z

name: NPR
text:
Since 2011, this Baltimore duo has donned Santa suits and delivered BBQ and Christmas trees to adoring locals.

"A tree and a smile mean more now," Mike Santoro says.

name: NPR
text: President Trump often takes credit for "unleashing America's scientific genius" in pursuit of a coronavirus vaccine. But immigrants have been involved in every facet of that effort, and people in the industry say U.S. genius depends on global talent. https://t.co/iJ5HlSvUEg

name: NPR
text:
A 60-year-old woman in New Mexico went to a local gynecologist after experiencing pelvic pain and cramping. The doctor did an exam and took a vaginal swab sample for lab testing.

Then the nightmare came.

A $12,386.93 fee.
https://t.co/I4rgaFQV3x

name: NPR
text:
The CDC first recommended Americans wear masks on April 3. 

Prisoners at Louisiana State Penitentiary, known as Angola, didn't get them until June or July, a former inmate says.

Even then, many eschewed them out of fear of being strangled.
https://t.co/epjxQkt1Mk

name: NPR
text:
The new coronavirus variant will likely come to the U.S. â€” if it isn't here already. But there's no evidence it causes more severe disease and scientists believe the vaccine will still be effective.
https://t.co/7PhRfKHMtC

name: NPR
text:
Dozens of lawsuits this year detail conditions that would make an epidemiologist shudder:

â€¢ Hundreds of inmates sharing communal spaces
â€¢ Jails and prisons over capacity
â€¢ Delays in isolating symptomatic inmates
â€¢ Lack of masks, soap, hand sanitizer 
https://t.co/fzyzkpmyND

name: NPR
text:
In March, a coronavirus outbreak at a New Jersey nursing home led state officials to evacuate all 78 of its residents.

Within weeks, nearly half of them were dead.

Did forced evacuation play a role in the deaths? We investigated.
https://t.co/F34mxF8ps9

name: NPR
text:
The CDC says all travelers coming from the U.K. must present a negative coronavirus test no more than 72 hours before taking a flight to the U.S. 

The new mandate comes after a new variant of the virus spread across England.
https://t.co/wYA9AYiLeI

text: Nancy Pelosi vowed House members would return Monday for a recorded vote on a stand-alone bill to raise direct relief payments to $2,000. https://t.co/cqDa40Anc2

name: NPR
text:
Developing: Nashville's downtown riverfront is being evacuated after an explosion shook the area around 6:30 on Christmas morning. @WPLN
https://t.co/bVckmMSc4z

name: NPR
text:
Every year, USPS makes children's letters to Santa available for anyone to "adopt" to help make their holiday wishes come true.

This year's letters offer a glimpse at the psyche of kids toughing it out through a crisis unlike anything they've experienced. https://t.co/32BUgZrOPK https://t.co/ZE9VdAnj2s

name: NPR
text:
Update: Police say the explosion in downtown Nashville was linked to a vehicle. Investigators believe it was intentional. @WPLN
https://t.co/CnrwpemfK8

name: NPR
text:
There have been reports that U.S. tourists could've contributed to coronavirus outbreaks in Mexico. But travelers aren't required to quarantine or test, so they're flocking there.

"There's no restrictions. ... We feel safe," a tourist in Los Cabos says.
https://t.co/EdOr6mQEV6
